Okay. Here's the thing. I've read through the comments of other viewers --- some trashing the film and some saying it's the funniest, most enjoyable work of kubrick they've seen. This movie is good for only one thing; teaching a baby: how to sleep in class.
Not only does this movie have a confused goal and bizarre ending, but all this dribble about homosexuality merely serves as a cheap substitute for any sort of human interest or circumstances

Well I don't know much about anything, but I sure liked this film. In short, it was creative, humorous, simple, and heartwarming. Okay so since you're unfamiliar with the film maybe you'd like a brief summary: A boy and his illegal group of slavers are on their way to deliver the female who they've kidnapped to their preacher/pimp leader when they decide that is just too bad for some kid that sand gets in his eyes. To

I'd even say some shades of Hitchcock...this is clearly better than MMM, which is seen as a guilty pleasure by some if not most Woody fans.
Hate to say this, but I disagree with the sentiment that Woody was considered in the same tier as Wilder or Kubrick. He had arguably one of his best movies in ANN and made what now appears to be a minor masterpiece with Stardust Memories kind of halfway between these two.<|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|><|end_of_text|>

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. "Les Valseuses" was remade as the 1985's "Too Beautiful to Die" and reworked again for Ridley Scott's Brother. A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The townspeople form an alliance against the mother, daughter, and son. A short story by Stephen King later released as an adaptation to this movie.
